description.value: Parameters resource used to evaluate the ServiceDefinition.

short.value: Operation Request or Response

definition.value: This special resource type is used to represent an operation request and response (operations.html). It has no other use, and there is no RESTful endpoint associated with it.

comment.value: The parameters that may be used are defined by the OperationDefinition resource.

short.value: Logical id of this artifact

definition.value: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.

comment.value: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation.

human.value: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

short.value: Metadata about the resource

definition.value: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content may not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

human.value: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

short.value: A set of rules under which this content was created

definition.value: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content.

comment.value:
Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element.
This element is labelled as a modifier because the implicit rules may provide additional knowledge about the resource that modifies it's meaning or interpretation.

human.value: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

short.value: Language of the resource content

definition.value: The base language in which the resource is written.

comment.value: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

human.value: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

short.value: Operation Parameter

definition.value: A parameter passed to or received from the operation.

human.value: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
A parameter must have only one of (value, resource, part)

expression.value: (part.exists() and value.empty() and resource.empty()) or (part.empty() and (value.exists() xor resource.exists()))

xpath.value: exists(f:value) or exists(f:resource) and not(exists(f:value) and exists(f:resource))

short.value: xml:id (or equivalent in JSON)

definition.value: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

comment.value: Note that FHIR strings may not exceed 1MB in size

human.value: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

description.value: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

short.value: Additional Content defined by implementations

definition.value: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.

comment.value: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions. The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

human.value: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

short.value: Extensions that cannot be ignored

definition.value: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

short.value: The person initiating the request.

definition.value: This MUST be populated by the EMS. The initiatingPerson is the user of the EMS. This will typically be a Patient or RelatedPerson if the EMS is being used by a member of the public (e.g. a patient-facing public internet system) or a Practitioner where initiatingOrganisation is populated. Note that this is the same as the receivingPerson.

short.value: Name from the definition

definition.value: The name of the parameter (reference to the operation definition).

comment.value: Note that FHIR strings may not exceed 1MB in size

human.value: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

short.value: If parameter is a data type

definition.value: If the parameter is a data type.

comment.value: A stream of bytes, base64 encoded

human.value: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

short.value: If parameter is a whole resource

definition.value: If the parameter is a whole resource.

short.value: Named part of a multi-part parameter

definition.value: A named part of a multi-part parameter.

comment.value: Only one level of nested parameters is allowed.

short.value: An optional client-provided identifier to track the request.

definition.value: MUST be provided by the EMS. This id MUST be persisted through a patient journey.

short.value: An optional client-provided identifier to track the request.

definition.value: An optional client-provided identifier to track the request.

short.value: These will be determined by the EMS and CDSS specific to each implementation.
The input data for the request.

definition.value: The inputData element MUST be populated with FHIR resources detailing the current state of the triage journey.

short.value: The patient in context, if any.

definition.value: This MUST be populated with a reference to a Patient resource.

short.value: The encounter in context, if any.

definition.value: This MUST be populated by the EMS with the logical Id of the Encounter.

short.value: The organization initiating the request.

definition.value: This SHOULD be populated by the EMS using the logical Id for the UEC service provider. Note that this is the same as the receivingOrganization. If this is an online (patient facing) system, then this MUST NOT be populated.

short.value: The person initiating the request.

definition.value: This MUST be populated by the EMS. The initiatingPerson is the user of the EMS. This will typically be a Patient or RelatedPerson if the EMS is being used by a member of the public (e.g. a patient-facing public internet system) or a Practitioner where initiatingOrganisation is populated. Note that this is the same as the receivingPerson.

short.value: The type of user initiating the request

definition.value: The userType parameter of note MUST be provided by the EMS. If the userType is patient, then the CDSS SHOULD use first person pronouns.

short.value: Preferred language of the person using the system.

definition.value: This SHOULD be provided by the EMS, based on the user requirements.

short.value: The task the system user is performing.

definition.value: This SHOULD be provided by the EMS, as it may be used to tailor decision support outputs.

short.value: The organization that will receive the response.

definition.value: This SHOULD be populated with the organisation identifier for the UEC service provider. If this is an online (patient facing) system, then this MUST NOT be populated. Note that this is the same as the initiatingOrganisation.

short.value: The person in the receiving organization that will receive the response.

definition.value: This MUST be populated by the EMS, based on the user. In the case of an online (patient-facing) system, this may be Patient or RelatedPerson. Note that this is the same as the initiatingPerson.

short.value: The type of individual that will consume the response content.

definition.value: This will be the patient (or a related person, if telephoning on behalf of the patient).

short.value: Preferred language of the person that will consume the content.

definition.value: This SHOULD be populated by the EMS where known for the recipient and will be populated with the same value as contained in the userLanguage parameter.

short.value: The current setting of the request (inpatient, outpatient, etc).

definition.value: This MUST be provided by the EMS to give context for decision support.

short.value: Additional detail about the setting.

definition.value: Additional detail about the setting of the request, if any.
